'''Fifteen birds in five fir-trees''' is a poem found within the chapter "[[Out of the Frying-Pan into the Fire]]" of ''[[The Hobbit]]''. It was sung by the [[Goblins]] to taunt [[Gandalf]], [[Bilbo Baggins|Bilbo]], and the [[Thorin and Company|thirteen Dwarves]] while the Goblins are setting fire to the trees in which they had taken refuge from the [[Wargs|wild wolves]].

==Poem excerpt==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">Fifteen birds in five fir-trees,
their feathers were fanned in a fiery breeze!
But, funny little birds, they had no wings!
O what shall we do with the funny little things?
Roast 'em alive, or stew them in a pot;
fry them, boil them and eat them hot?</poem>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''1977: [[The Hobbit (1977 film)|''The Hobbit'' (1977 film)]]:'''
:The [[Orcs|Goblins]] sing a version of the song while they chase [[Thorin and Company]]. It is titled "[[Funny Little Things]]" on [[The Hobbit: The Complete Original Soundtrack|the soundtrack]].
